Comment: but also husband, people of other tribes

Gloss: wooden planks above stone and mud base

Comment: Probably related to widespread Tibeto-Burman #-luŋ, e.g. Dirang luŋ, Lepcha lɔŋ, Rawang lúŋ, Limbu luŋ etc.

Widespread in regional Tibeto-Burman languages, e.g. Tawang Monpa palap, Lepcha lɔp, Jingpho làp, Rawang ʃəláp. Probably also related are the Tibeto-Burman roots with no final, such as Mikir lò. Also in regional isolates such as Miju lap, Meyor alap.
murarau market u na ba? why did you go to the market?
kʰoo gamogimi ba ‘the water is lukewarm’
nimi saŋsaŋ ba the sky is clear
i.e. ‘not healthy’ ki ahaŋ bo ‘body healthy not’
yo asiŋ ba my clothes are wet
lumu bʧikba romo la I took the wrong road
ba wotpa the fire is blazing
yam zeŋba house is being constructed
gui Roger anba I am called Roger
ʤo ʧanbɔ the tea is getting cold
wai andukpa I told him [to go]
simʧa na rekba bʤabba ramne animals destroyed the field
wa gui daŋbo he is disturbing me
ʧaluk hĩmupa the orange fell down
kʰo hawba the river is flowing
i.e. where the river is going
i.e. towards the head of the river
kow bə rumba knock on the door
bʧa ayuŋ keba the hen laid an egg
wa bʧikpa rampa he has made a mistake
par are Tibetan-style scriptures, this expression refers to printing on cloths that hand outside the house
ko tʰiba ʧamo run to that side
kʰo boŋ pʰiŋ loba play in the water
ba waŋ ray turn on the light
